sen.j: 賢憬（けんけい、和銅7年（714年） - 延暦12年11月8日 (旧暦)（793年12月15日））は、奈良時代の法相宗の僧。
sen.e: Kenkei (714 - Dec 15, 793) was a Hosso sect Buddhist priest during the Nara period.
Kenkei (714 - December 15, 793) was a Buddhist priest of Hosso sect of Buddhism (Japanese equivalent of the Chinese Faxiang sect or Dharma-character school), who lived in the Nara period.
sen.cmt: 形式・用語・表現を修正しました
sen.e: Kenkei (714 - December 15, 793) was a Buddhist priest of Hosso sect of Buddhism (Japanese equivalent of the Chinese Faxiang sect or Dharma-character school), who lived in the Nara period.
His lay clan name was Aratai.
His secular surname was Aratai.
His secular surname was Aratai.
He was born in Owari Province.
He was born in Owari Province.
He was born in Owari Province.

sen.j: 賢璟（けんきょう）とも称される。
sen.e: He also went by the name `Kenkyo`.
He also went by the name Kenkyo.
He also went by the name Kenkyo.

sen.j: 尾張僧都あるいは尾張大僧都とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: He was called the `priest of Owari` or `Head Priest of Owari`.
He was called Owari Sozu (literally, high priest of Owari) or Owari Daisozu (literally, head priest of Owari).
sen.cmt: 用語・形式を修正しました
sen.e: He was called Owari Sozu (literally, high priest of Owari) or Owari Daisozu (literally, head priest of Owari).

sen.j: 興福寺宣教に師事して唯識法相を学ぶ一方で苦業練行を重ね、天平15年（743年）正月に「師主元興寺賢璟」として同族の子麻呂を優婆塞に貢進推挙した。
sen.e: He studied Yogacara school of Buddhism at the Kofuku-ji temple seminary and also trained in painful karma whereupon, in the new year of 743 as `The Master Kenyo of Kofuku-ji temple ` he was commended for service by Prince Komaro of the imperial family.

Under Senkyo, master of the Hosso sect at Kofuku-ji Temple, Kenkei studied vijnapti-matrata or Consciousness-only school (aka Yuishiki or wei shih, i.e. a theory that all existence is subjective and nothing exists outside of the mind) and dharmalaksana or Dharma-character school (aka Hosso or faxiang, i.e. the specific characteristics of all manifest phenomena), and also practiced a kind of asceticism called kugo-rengyo, and in the new year of 743, as Shishu (Master) Kenkei of Kofuku-ji Temple he nominated Komaro, who was his relative, for becoming an ubasoku (aka upasaka, referring to a lay servant).
sen.cmt: 誤解釈箇所を加筆修正しました。用語を修正しました。
sen.e: Under Senkyo, master of the Hosso sect at Kofuku-ji Temple, Kenkei studied vijnapti-matrata or Consciousness-only school (aka Yuishiki or wei shih, i.e. a theory that all existence is subjective and nothing exists outside of the mind) and dharmalaksana or Dharma-character school (aka Hosso or faxiang, i.e. the specific characteristics of all manifest phenomena), and also practiced a kind of asceticism called kugo-rengyo, and in the new year of 743, as Shishu (Master) Kenkei of Kofuku-ji Temple he nominated Komaro, who was his relative, for becoming an ubasoku (aka upasaka, referring to a lay servant).

sen.j: 754年（天平勝宝6年）唐の僧鑑真を難波に迎え、翌755年（天平勝宝7年）には旧戒を破棄して鑑真から具足戒を受けた。
sen.e: In 754 the T`ang priest named Ganjin was welcomed to the Naniwa region and in the following year (755) the former Buddhist precepts were abandoned and a replete set received from Ganjin.
sen.cmt: 宝7歳>>7年だと思われます。
sen.e: In 754, the Tang priest named Ganjin (aka Janzen) was welcomed to Naniwa, and in the following year of 755, Kenkei abandoned the former Buddhist precepts and received gusokukai (i.e. full precepts) from Ganjin.
sen.cmt: 用語・表現を修正しました。原文の誤字を修正しました。
sen.e: In 754, the Tang priest named Ganjin (aka Janzen) was welcomed to Naniwa, and in the following year of 755, Kenkei abandoned the former Buddhist precepts and received gusokukai (i.e. full precepts) from Ganjin.

sen.j: 758年（天平宝字2年）には唐招提寺に一切経420巻を奉納している。
sen.e: In 758 a full set of 420 Buddhist sutras were provided to Toshodai-ji temple.
In 758, he dedicated a full set of 420 scrolls of Buddhist sutras to Toshodai-ji Temple.
In 758, he dedicated a full set of 420 scrolls of Buddhist sutras to Toshodai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 774年（宝亀5年）に律師に任じられている。
sen.e: In 774 he served as Preceptor.
In 774, he served as Risshi (literally, preceptor, referring to the third rank of priest following Sojo and Sozu).
In 774, he served as Risshi (literally, preceptor, referring to the third rank of priest following Sojo and Sozu).

sen.j: 宝亀9年（778年）頃に大和国室生山で延寿法を修して山部皇太子（後の桓武天皇）の宿痾を治したために、後に桓武天皇の深い信頼を得た。
sen.e: Circa 778 he earned the profound trust of Crown Prince Yamabe (later to be Emperor Kammu) who was at Mt. Muro in Yamato Province and studying the 延寿法 in order to cure an illness he was suffering from.
sen.cmt: 延寿法の訳が不明です。
sen.e: Circa 778, he mastered enju-ho (literally, prayers for life prolonging) at Mt. Murou in Yamato Province and cured a chronic disease Crown Prince Yamabe (the future Emperor Kammu) was suffering from, thereby earning the profound trust of the prince.
sen.cmt: 誤解釈箇所を加筆修正しました。用語を修正しました。
sen.e: Circa 778, he mastered enju-ho (literally, prayers for life prolonging) at Mt. Murou in Yamato Province and cured a chronic disease Crown Prince Yamabe (the future Emperor Kammu) was suffering from, thereby earning the profound trust of the prince.

sen.j: 780年（宝亀11年）多度大社神宮寺に三重塔を建立、また宝亀年間（770年－780年）には室生寺を創建している。
sen.e: He built a 3 storied pagoda at the Jingu-ji temple at Tadotaisha shrine and, between the period 770 - 780 he established Muro-ji temple.
In 780, Kenkei built a three-storied pagoda at Jingu-ji Temple at Tado-taisha Shrine, and during the Hoki era (770-780) he established Murou-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 用語・表現・形式を修正しました。
sen.e: In 780, Kenkei built a three-storied pagoda at Jingu-ji Temple at Tado-taisha Shrine, and during the Hoki era (770-780) he established Murou-ji Temple.

sen.j: 784年（延暦3年）大僧都に任じられる。
sen.e: In 784 he was given the Buddhist priest rank of Dai-soku (one of 4 second tier ranks).
In 784, he was given the Buddhist priest rank of Daisozu.
In 784, he was given the Buddhist priest rank of Daisozu.

sen.j: 延暦4年4月（785年5月）の最澄の戒牒や『多度神宮寺伽藍縁起並資財帳』に、ともに僧綱の一人として署名した。
sen.e: In April 785 his name appears as a member of the Sogo (ancient Buddhist ecclesiastical authority) in both ordination documents of a Buddhist priest named Saicho and, a document entitled `Directory of Tado Jingu-ji temple origins and property`.

In Saicho's kaicho (Certificates of Reception of Buddhist Commandments) of May 785, and in "Tado-jinguji garan engi narabini shizai cho" (literally, directory of Tado Jingu-ji Temple origins and property), he signed his name as a member of Sogo (ancient Buddhist ecclesiastical authority).
sen.cmt: 原文に対応西暦月を補足のうえ、文脈・用語・表現を修正しました
sen.e: In Saicho's kaicho (Certificates of Reception of Buddhist Commandments) of May 785, and in "Tado-jinguji garan engi narabini shizai cho" (literally, directory of Tado Jingu-ji Temple origins and property), he signed his name as a member of Sogo (ancient Buddhist ecclesiastical authority).

sen.j: 793年（延暦12年）遷都を行うにあたって遷都先の地を選ぶ際、山背（山城国）の地に派遣されている。
sen.e: When a location was selected for the shift of the capital 793, he was dispatched to a site in Yamase (in Yamashiro Province).
When a location was selected for the shift of the capital in 793, he was dispatched to a site in Yamashiro (in Yamashiro Province).
sen.cmt: 前置詞を追加し、地名を修正しました
sen.e: When a location was selected for the shift of the capital in 793, he was dispatched to a site in Yamashiro (in Yamashiro Province).

sen.j: その際、比叡山文殊堂供養で導師をつとめている。
sen.e: On that occasion, he was the officiating Buddhist monk at a memorial service at Mt. Hiei.
On that occasion, he served as doshi (officiating Buddhist priest) at a memorial service at Monju-do Hall of Mt. Hiei.
sen.cmt: 用語・表現を修正しました。
sen.e: On that occasion, he served as doshi (officiating Buddhist priest) at a memorial service at Monju-do Hall of Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: 同年11月8日(793年12月15日）に80歳で没した。
sen.e: Kenkei passed away aged 80 in Nov 793.
Kenkei passed away at the age of 80 in December 15, 793.
sen.cmt: 原文に対応西暦日付を補足のうえ再訳出しました。表現・形式を修正しました
sen.e: Kenkei passed away at the age of 80 in December 15, 793.

sen.j: 高い学識で知られ、大安寺戒明が入唐求法で請来した「釈摩訶衍論」を調べてこれを偽書と判定し、最澄と会津の徳一との論争に影響を与えた。
sen.e: Known for his prodigious scholarship he delved into the text 'Sakumakaenron` 釈摩訶衍論 (annotated 10 volume translated Mahayana Buddhism text brought back from T`ang China by Buddhist priest Kaimyo of Daian-ji temple) coming to the conclusion it was a fake, which influenced the dispute the priests Saicho and Aizu had with the priest Tokuitsu.

Known for his prodigious scholarship he delved into the text 'Shakumakaenron' (annotated 10 volume translated Mahayana Buddhism text brought back from Tang China by Buddhist priest Kaimyo of Daian-ji Temple during his Nitto Guho [a pilgrimage to China in search of the Law]) coming to the conclusion it was a fake, which influenced the dispute between Saicho and Tokuitsu of Aizu.

sen.j: 多くの弟子がいたが、その中でも修円・明福は有名である。
sen.e: Amongst his many acolytes, Shuen and Myofuku are famous.
